doc.title: Strategy - Thailand
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Takeaways from Thailand Focus Day 2Takeaways from Thailand Focus Day 2_2025-08-29

passages.text: ADVANC (Buy): ADVANC said market share gain was due to network quality and price war refinement. Further cost- savings from fixed broadband is minimal in their view.

BGRIM (U/P): BGRIM maintains its 2025 new IU synchronization target of 45MW while the progress of a 96MW- data center is on track with \(12 - 15\%\) EIRR expected. Vietnam's FiT cut will likely impact Bt300- 400mn of NPAT p.a. in the worst case.

CBG (U/P): Carabao has gained significant share in the domestic market and aims to be on par with the market leader by this year. Cambodia remains a risk to the top line and operation in Myanmar faces some friction.

CPALL (Buy): QTD same- store sales are expected to improve from last quarter with retail margin expansion through better product mix. CPALL aims to maintain high- single- digit revenue growth in the long- term.

MINT (Buy): Management is confident in its 2025 core profit growth target of \(15 - 20\%\) with at least double- digit growth in a weaker macro scenario. Hotel RevPAR is expected to improve from August onwards based on forward bookings and Thai restaurants' positive SSSG continues QTD.

PTT (Buy): Formation of PTT's power flagship to divest assets is expected to raise Bt30bn in 2H25. The Genesis project (shortlist for strategic partners expected in 4Q25; closure in 2026) should generate Bt77bn in 2026 with no equity raising needed at PTTGC/TOP. GSP's profitability hit from pool- gas price reform is likely to have peaked.

SCGP (U/P): Growth in 2H is guided to be flat with packaging business continuing to recover, while fibrous business still faces headwinds. Fajar losses narrowed towards EBITDA breakeven. The management targets 1.5- 2.0x of EBITDA growth in five years supported by organic growth and M&P strategy.

BBL (Not Rated): BBL sees full- year loan growth at \(2 - 3\%\) and guides for \(2.8\%\) NIM in 2025. Credit costs are front- loaded. Cost- to- income could end lower than guidance, and NPLs are manageable. Restructuring since 2024 should keep NPLs below \(3.5\%\) .

KTC (Not Rated): Management remains cautious on the personal loan growth outlook. However, it emphasizes sustainability in dividend distributions and its leveraging potential in given its relatively low debt- to- equity ratio.

TLI (Not Rated): Lower interest rate cycle and a higher share of endowment product sales will be significant headwinds for margins according to management. Nevertheless, TLI still anticipates positive growth in both VONB and CSM.

IU - Industrial user
FiT - Feed- in tariff
GSP - Gas Separation Plant
M&P - Merge and Partner
VONB - Value of New Business
CSM - Contractual service margin
EIRR - Economic internal rate of return
RTE - Ready- to- eat
RTD - Ready- to- drink
OCI - Other Comprehensive Income

ADVANC's market share gain was primarily due to network quality as the company refrained from an aggressive pricing strategy. ADVANC utilized 700MHz spectrum bought from National Telecom (NT) to improve network quality in the area where its market share is below its competitors.

ADVANC maintains two fixed broadband brands (3BB and AIS Fiber) as the regulator requires two separate brands for three years after 3BB acquisition. However, ADVANC will integrate these two brands into one in 2026. This is not likely to lead to material marketing cost savings as ADVANC has already optimized fixed broadband marketing spending.
ADVANC has recently won the right to broadcast the National Basketball Association (NBA) basketball matches. Costs and NBA package have not yet been revealed.

The company guided for average gas cost of Bt310- 330/mmBtu, implying steady cogeneration margin to that in 1Q25. We believe that with the current strong baht it could imply more easy gas cost in 4Q25. Meanwhile the company aims to sync an additional 25MW in 2H25 making full- year sync of 45MW, in line with its initial target. The company expects to bring online ARECO (Philippines solar farm 65MW) late this year while Nakowl (offshore wind farm) could be partially online in late 4Q25.

For Vietnam, the company guided that the Vietnam government should finalize the decision on renewable FiT (from 9.35 cents to 7 cents) in the next few months. They believe the decision could be reasonable to the operators. Note that according to the company, under the worst- case scenario that the FiT is to be cut, it will affect NPAT by around Bt300- 400m per annum.

The progress of its 96MW- data center (JV with Digital Edge) is on track. The project value will be Bt25mn and will be separated into phases (48MW each). Currently the project already has acquired land and secured BOI approval while their partner (Digital Edge) is in charge of customer acquisition. The company maintains its EIRR guidance of around 12- 15%.
The Cambodian economy is likely to suffer from border tension. It is too soon to estimate the potential impact on CBG's sales.

Distributors have started doing campaigns ahead of the Myanmar factory operation commencement. However, the import license has recently become scarce (due to the lack of USD in Myanmar) and this could make it difficult to implement energy drink concentrate and aluminum cans.

Carabao's volume market share in the domestic market has grown to \(26.5\%\) from \(19.9\%\) in 2022. CBG targets to grow its market share to \(29\%\) within \(25\%\) (versus market leader share of \(30.1\%\) ). CBG has gained market share in Bangkok Central and Northeastern regions.
Spirits market share has grown to \(18\%\) from \(16\%\) last year. Quality of product (which is positioned as a premium brand) is the key driver of market share gain.

Bangkok hotel RevPAR fell \(4\%\) YoY in July but is expected to recover to flat YoY by 4Q25. Centara at CentralWorld has improved with stronger Middle East demand, particularly from Saudi guests. Together with upcountry hotels, forward bookings suggest Thailand hotel revenue in 4Q25 will grow about \(5\%\) YoY.

New Maldives hotels saw OCC rate improve from \(16\%\) in 2Q25 to \(35\%\) in July and 40- \(45\%\) in August. Management expects only a slim loss in 4Q25 (Centara Grand to turn profitable, Mirage still loss- making) and full profitability from 1Q26.

Existing Maldives hotels adopted a strategy of reducing ADR by \(5 - 10\%\) to lift occupancy. As a result, on- the- book revenue is up \(9\%\) YoY in September, with 4Q25 OCC rate at \(43\%\) now and expected to end 4Q25 at \(70 - 75\%\) (vs. \(58\%\) in 4Q24).
Japan hotels saw RevPAR drop \(7\%\) YoY in July on earthquake concerns, but rebounded strongly: \(+19\%\) YoY in August, \(+37\%\) in September, and \(+35\%\) in 4Q25 based on forward bookings.

Food business SSSG improved from \(- 3\%\) YoY ex- JV \((- 2\%\) incl. JV) in 2Q25 to flat ex- JV and \(+1\%\) including JV in July. Shinkansen Sushi recorded double- digit YoY SSSG, while KFC remains negative but the gap is narrowing. Management expects to complete one M&A by year- end, likely under a JV structure, with revenue scale ranking among CENTEL's top five brands.

QTD SSS should improve from that in 2Q25 with QTD SSS running at slight positive from improving weather conditions. Retail margin should also expand through product mix led by RTE, RTD, personal care, and health and beauty products. The company continued to expand 700 CVS in Thailand and 10 CVS in Laos.

For the long term, they believe they should be able to maintain revenue growth at high single digits from store expansion (5%) and SSS (growing in line with GDP growth). The company also expects margin expansion of 10- 20bp through product mix. This target is in line with our expectations.

Thailand hotels' RevPAR declined by mid- single digits YoY in July due to major renovations, while European hotels' RevPAR slipped to low- single digits YoY on last- year's high base. From August onward, the base effect should normalize, with forward bookings pointing to growth in 3Q25. Several events and trade fairs should further support RevPAR growth in 4Q25.
Maldives hotels remain strong, with RevPAR growth above \(20\%\) YoY in July.
Thai restaurants posted positive SSSG QTD, while China restaurants also recorded low- single- digit positive SSSG in July.
Management remains confident in its 2025 core profit growth target of \(15 - 20\%\) . Even in a weaker macro scenario, growth should still be at least double- digits in their view.
On the REIT update, management expects completion in 1Q26, targeting a \(7 - 8\%\) yield, with a preference to list in Singapore rather than in Thailand.

PTT's group asset monetization plan includes 1) the creation of PTT's power flagship in which power assets of PTTGC, TOP, and IRPC will be injected into this new entity 2) Infrastructure flagship, which will be set up to absorb infrastructure/logistics assets (networks of pipelines, tank farms) of PTTGC, TOP, and IRPC. 3) non- hydrocarbon asset (EV- related assets) divestment 4) other assets. This plan is expected to generate around Bt30bn of new proceeds (excluding the intercompany transactions) to PTT in 2H25.

Genesis project, in which PTT is expected to sell down its stakes in PTTGC, TOP, and IRPC to pave the way for new strategic partners, should announce a shortlist of potential partners in 4Q25. The shortlist can be divided into three groups (feedstock suppliers, global energy traders, National oil companies NOCs) and oil majors.

Genesis is expected to be wrapped up in 2026 and it will represent a major part of net proceeds (Bt77bn) that PTT plans to receive from its asset monetization plan in 2026. We understand that PTT and its affiliates are under Genesis's due diligence process. We do not believe that there is need for PTTGC and TOP to increase its capital to pave the way for the new strategic partners. While it is premature to come up with the pricing for these transactions, PTT indicated that the pricings would have to reflect long- term growth potential or recovery of these entities in addition to the current cyclical downturn of the chemical industry.

The finalization of GSP's pool gas price restructuring is expected to improve GSP's profitability which has hit the bottom (characterized as negative EBITDA) in 2Q25 although the timeline remains uncertain. The previous schedule is for GSP's pool gas price restructuring to be concluded in 2025.

Management remains optimistic. They guided for flat HoH performance in 2H25, with slight YoY sales growth already seen in July despite market concerns over front- loaded demand ahead of US tariffs. 3Q25 earnings are expected to sustain QoQ. Packaging business (80% of revenue) continues to recover, while fibrous business (20%) faces headwinds from declining pulp prices.

Fajar losses narrowed towards EBITDA breakeven following debt restructuring in July. SCGP expects Fajar to contribute - Bt60mn net profit per quarter starting 3Q25. Strategy focuses on domestic sales (higher margins vs. exports to China) and cost control.
Asset rationalization and M&P (Merge and Partner) remain key long- term levers. Ongoing negotiations on downstream acquisition (box manufacturing) to strengthen returns.

The management aims for 1.5- 2.0x of EBITDA growth target for the next five years boosted by organic growth and M&P strategy (Bt16bn in 2024A). The normal CAPEX guidance is maintained at - Bt13bn/year.

The GDP growth forecast for 2025 remains at \(1.5 - 2\%\) , though uncertainties persist and additional downside risks could emerge. China's exports to ASEAN rose \(16\%\) while shipments to the US contracted \(7\%\) , with exports to Thailand still expanding \(28\%\) year- on- year in May 2025. The Bt200bn impact on the agriculture sector is seen as manageable, mostly affecting corn farmers, while the greater concern lies with SMEs facing competitive pressure from Chinese imports.

Tourism continues to improve and FDI remains strong, with Board of Investment applications reaching a record Bt1 trillion in the first half of 2025, led by agriculture, electronics, EV and data centers. Geopolitical friction between the US and China, as well as India and Pakistan, may ultimately benefit ASEAN economies, though the positive effects are likely to materialize over the next five years. The structural transition away from legacy industries such as textiles and media will also take several years before new economic drivers can fully compensate.

Private consumption growth slowed to \(2.5\%\) year- on- year, while manufacturing rose less than \(1\%\) in the second quarter. Household deleveraging remains a drag, driven mainly by the informal financial system rather than commercial banks. Retail loans are under pressure, but the corporate segment is in a stronger position.

BBL's loans grew just \(0.7\%\) year- to- date in the first half and is expected to be back- loaded into the fourth quarter, with full- year growth targeted at \(2 - 3\%\) . Permata Bank achieved \(5\%\) loan growth in local currency terms in 1H25.

Margins held at \(2.85\%\) in the first half of 2025, with some widening seen in the seven- month period due to deposit repricing. The bank still expects to achieve the low end of its full- year NIM guidance at \(2.8\%\) , compared with \(3.04\%\) previously. Credit costs were front- loaded, with provisions ending near 2024's level of Bt34.8bn. Cost- to- income ratios could end lower than guidance, and NPLs remain manageable, with restructuring efforts since late 2024 expected to keep the NPL ratio below \(3.5\%\) .

KTC's outlook for personal loan growth has become more cautious, mainly due to lower interest rate charges and ongoing structural challenges in the Thai economy. Even though lower- income segments are not particularly sensitive to interest rate reductions, the risk- reward profile is not appealing thus far in our view.

In terms of competitive positioning, there is limited overlap with its competitor, AEONTS. AEONTS focuses primarily on personal loans and targets the lower- income segment, while KTC's core strength remains in credit cards. For personal loans, KTC's portfolio is concentrated in the THB 12,000- 30,000 income range, accounting for roughly 70 percent of its total loan book. KTC views personal loans as a pathway to transition customers into credit card products over time. The migration rate from personal loans to credit cards is about \(16\%\) . For overall credit card business, \(30\%\) of total accounts are revolving but they make up \(70\%\) of total credit card loans. Meanwhile, the average retention rate for credit card customers stands at around \(60\%\) .

Collaboration with KTB provides an important customer acquisition channel for KTC. The partnership has proven successful in cross- selling, with KTC leveraging KTB's payroll customer base to expand credit card adoption.

On dividends, KTC has a policy of paying a minimum of 40 percent of earnings. The board emphasizes sustainability in distributions, with governance comprising two directors from KTB, the CEO, and five independent directors.

Management had expected a strong rebound in loan growth after COVID, but the recovery has fallen short for the past two years. As a result, capital has been building up more quickly than anticipated. The company also believes its current debt- to- equity ratio is too low, leaving it under- leveraged relative to its balance sheet capacity.

Asset quality remains strong, with non- performing loans defined as those overdue by more than 90 days. The company writes off loans that are overdue for more than six months. Restructured loans account for about 3 percent of the portfolio, classified under either Stage 1 or Special Mention.

TLI, established in 1942, is Thailand's largest life insurer with more than 83 years of history. The company went public in 2022 and joined the SET50 the same year, with a strategic target of achieving an AA ESG rating.

The company's distribution model is anchored by its agency network, which contributes \(65\%\) of sales, alongside an exclusive bancassurance partnership with BAY. The agency channel focuses on higher- value products and holds the second- largest market share nationwide. On average, agency customers own three to four policies—typically whole life, medical rider, and accident rider—while bancassurance customers tend to hold only a single endowment policy. TLI plans to strengthen its agency model by introducing AI tools to complement sales forces and services, while also expanding into financial advisory.

The mid to long-term vision is to evolve into a life solutions partner, offering policies tailored to customer needs across different life stages. The agency channel remains crucial, not only for policy sales but also for after-sales support, including claims assistance and policy servicing. Personalized insurance products are expected to be launched next year, enhancing TLI's holistic customer value proposition.

Bancassurance, by contrast, has gained traction mainly in savings products such as endowments, investment- linked, and participating policies, particularly in the current low interest rate environment. TLI faces its main competition from AIA and leading banks. While AIA holds a \(25\%\) market share compared to TLI's \(12 - 13\%\) , TLI differentiates itself through its extensive nationwide agency presence, whereas competitors are more concentrated in Bangkok. Product- wise, TLI maintains a smaller share of investment- linked products due to its larger exposure to upcountry policyholders.

Claims are mostly concentrated in health riders. The recently introduced co- payment scheme may help reduce claim ratios, though its effectiveness is yet to be proven. Without it, persistently high claim ratios could force the company to raise health rider premiums, as health insurance pricing cannot be adjusted individually like non- life insurance.

On the financial side, the impact of rate cuts is limited to new policy investments, with only around \(20\%\) churn. The investment portfolio is managed with short duration, so large valuation swings are not expected, and most revaluations flow through OCI on both assets and liabilities. By theory, lower rates would compress VONB margins, but TLI has already extended its asset duration to lock in higher yields. The portfolio mix stands at \(87\%\) fixed income and \(13\%\) equities, of which \(90\%\) are Thai stocks.

Looking ahead, 2H25 is expected to be challenging given margin pressure from lower rates and a higher share of endowment product sales. Nevertheless, management still anticipates positive growth in both VONB and CSM.

Our PO for ADVANC is revised up to Bt336 following our earnings upgrade, derived from the average of our DCF value and target EV/EBITDA fair value. Our updated DCF valuation is Bt360 (using an \(8\%\) WACC and a \(1.0\%\) terminal growth rate), while our EV/EBITDA fair value is Bt301 based on 2025E EBITDA and an unchanged 8.2x target multiple.

The downside risk stems from increased competition from rivals, which could pressure market share and profitability. The upside risk lies in the potential spectrum auction in late 2026 for the 3500MHz band
B.Grimm Power (XVSGF)

We arrive at our price objective of Bt10.7 for BGRIM based DCF valuation. Our DCF valuation is based on the company's 14- year cash flow during 2025- 2040E based on WACC of \(8.5 - 11.0\%\) during the forecast period. The WACC used is based on a risk- free rate assumption of \(3\%\) , equity risk premium of \(8\%\) , beta of \(1.65x\) and average cost of debt net of tax of \(4\%\) . Note that the beta target is based on the company's two- year average during 2023- 2024. Our terminal growth rate is \(1\%\) , given our anticipation of slowdown in sales growth given cap in power tariffs.

The upside risks are (1) higher- than- expected volume sales to IU for both power and steam sales, (2) better- than- expected plant efficiency, (3) a sharp decline in fuel cost, (4) higher- than- expected Ft increase and (5) lower- than- expected funding cost following debt refinancing.

The downside risks are (1) unplanned shutdowns of power plants, (2) sharp rises in fuel cost, (3) lower- than- expected Ft increase, (4) lower- than- expected demand from IU, (5) interest rate volatility and (6) longer- than- expected development.

We use an average of DCF valuation and target P/E fair value in establishing our Bt54 PO. DCF valuation using \(7\%\) WACC and \(2\%\) terminal growth rate is Bt60 per share. Target P/E fair value is Bt48 per share. For target P/E fair value, we use 2026E EPS and 16x target P/E which is based on CBG's two standard deviations below mean P/E from 2014 until present, which we think is reasonable given risk from the Thai- Cambodian conflict.

Downside risks are lower- than- expected sales in Cambodia due to the ongoing Thailand- Cambodia conflict and more intense- than- expected domestic price competition. Upside risk is revenue from distribution and OEM contract which could beat our target if the beer products perform better than expected.

Our PO is based on average between DCF and PER target. We use DCF methodology for earnings estimate from 2025- 2035 to value CENTEL to capture the full investment cycle of hotel expansion. We use risk- free rate of \(3\%\) , a market risk premium of \(8\%\) , average 2- year beta of \(1.2x\) and a terminal growth rate of \(2.5\%\) . Our PER target is \(22x\) , relatively inline with peer average and lower than \(28x\) of historical average.

Upside risks are pick up in consumption, stronger- than- expected growth from its hotel management business, and value- accretive acquisitions. Downside risks are major political disruption in Thailand, a collapse in domestic consumption, and cancellation of management contracts.
Our PO of Bt70 is based on the average between our DCF valuation (Bt70) and our PE valuation (Bt70).

For our DCF valuation, our WACC calculation is based on a risk- free rate of \(3\%\) and a market risk premium of \(8\%\) . Our beta applied is \(1.15x\) which is the company's latest two- year historical average. We apply a \(3\%\) terminal growth rate.

Our PER target is 22x which is the company's one standard deviation below its 14- year historical average given (1) the contribution from Lotus's hypermarket operations, for which the market assigns a PER that is lower than other grocery retail formats, and (2) potential downside risk from CPAXT's (in which CPALL holds \(60\%\) ) recent investment in the Happitat.

Upside risks are a faster- than- expected operation recovery for CPALL and its subsidiaries, a stronger- than- expected consumption outlook resulting in better- than- expected performance of relevant peers, an improvement in the company's corporate governance image and the divestment of MAKRO shares which should improve the company's balance sheet.

Downside risks are lower- than- expected EBITDA (and equity contribution) from its operation (and Lotus's) due to a slowdown in the economic outlook, corporate governance risk and any aggressive acquisitions which could trigger a cash call.
Our PO of Bt38.0/share is based on our DCF valuation.

We use DCF methodology for earnings estimate from 2025- 2035 to value MINT to capture the full investment cycle of hotel expansion. We use risk- free rate of \(3\%\) , a market risk premium of \(8\%\) , average beta of 1.3x and a terminal growth rate of \(2.5\%\) .

Upside risks are faster than expected growth in its key markets i.e. Europe, Thailand, Maldives, etc. Downside risks to our PO are hotels RevPAR contraction from higher supply and/or demand slow- down, slower- than- expected sales of residential projects, and cancellation of management contracts.

Our Bt40.0PO is based on SOTP valuation. For PTT's SOTP, we value the E&P based on our average price assumptions of US\(5.8/mmbtu (gas) and US\)62/bbl (liquid) with a WACC of \(10.1\%\) . Our GRM for Thai Oil (TOP) is US\(9.2/bbl versus the average cash operating cost of US\)2.5/bbl. We use WACC of \(12.2\%\) . For PTT Global Chemical's (PTTGC) DCF valuation, we use WACC of \(11.5\%\) . The DCF is based on an average olefin cracker EBITDA spread of US\)77/ton, polymer EBITDA of US\)132/ton, and overall GIM of US\)8.7/bbl. For PTT's gas group valuation, its average EBITDA is US\)98/ton for the gas separation unit (GSP) unit, Bt16.8/mmbtu for the gas transmission unit, and Bt11.4/mmbtu for the supply and marketing (S&M) unit.

Its petrochemical/refinery is valued on P/E, P/B, and DCF. We use a P/E of 10.5x for the refinery unit (TOP) and target P/B of 0.85x, both of which are the average of TOP's historical range with a \(15\%\) discount rate to reflect GRM volatility and regulatory risk. We think this is appropriate given an increase in regulatory risk manifested in 2022. We use 8.8x P/E multiple and 1.0x P/B multiple for the petrochemical unit (PTTGC). PTTGC's target multiple is at the average of the trading range with a \(15\%\) discount.

The risks to our PO are volatility in gas/oil prices, petrochemical spread/price fluctuations, potential government intervention at its oil retail business, regulatory risks, sovereign/political uncertainty in Thailand, and construction risks.

Our PO of Bt15.80 is based on 2026E at EV/EBITDA target of 9.2x, nearly 2 standard deviations below its long- term mean since IPO in 2020, as we expect EBITDA margin of \(10.9\%\) for 2026E, which is below the \(15.1\%\) 2015- 2024 mean.
Our 9.2x EV/EBITDA target is derived from a) 10x EV/EBITDA target for integrated packaging chain (80% of the group) and 2) 6x EV/EBITDA target for fibrous chain (20%
of the group), in line with the global peers.

The upside risks are 1) significantly higher economic growth and demand recovery in ASEAN and China, 2) better- than- expected of export demand particularly to China, 3) higher product prices, 3) speed up bottom- line turnaround for Fajar, 4) better cost reduction given economies of scale, cost efficiency program and improving margin.

The downside risks are 1) significantly lower economic growth particularly for ASEAN and China, 2) higher- than- expected capacity expansion, 3) higher- than- expected increase in raw material prices, freight costs and coal prices.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage clusterR2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%
R2Ratings dispersions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster.

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (divided considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (divided not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
